content:
Problem # leetcode 1 - Two Sum (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: nums = [2, 7, 11, 15], target = 9 Output: [0, 1] Example 2:
Input: nums = [3, 2, 4], target = 6 Output: [1, 2] Solution # This problem requires finding two numbers in an array that add up to a given target, and returning their indices. This is a classic HashMap problem, which can be efficiently solved using a hash map with a time complexity of O(n).
Approach # We can use a hash map to store each number’s index. As we iterate through the array, we check if there is a number such that target - nums[i] equals a number that has already appeared. If it exists, we return the indices of these two numbers.
Steps:
Initialize an empty hash map map to store the value and index of numbers. Iterate through the array nums. For each element nums[i], calculate target - nums[i] and check if this difference exists in the hash map. If it exists, return the indices of these two numbers. If it does not exist, store the current number and its index in the hash map. Example Explanation: nums = [2, 7, 11, 15], target = 9 # Initial state: map = {}, target = 9. We iterate through each number in nums. Processing the first number 2:
Calculate target - 2 = 9 - 2 = 7. map does not contain 7, so store 2 and its index 0 in the map, map = {2: 0}. Processing the second number 7:
Calculate target - 7 = 9 - 7 = 2. map contains 2, so return map.get(2) and the current index 1, i.e., return [0, 1]. Thus, the answer is [0, 1], indicating nums[0] + nums[1] = 9.
Code # import java.util.Map; import java.util.HashMap; class Solution { public int[] twoSum(int[] nums, int target) { Map<Integer, Integer> map = new HashMap<>(); // Initialize a hash map to store numbers and indices for (int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) { // Iterate through the array if (map.containsKey(target - nums[i])) { // Check if the hash map contains the target number's difference return new int[] { map.get(target - nums[i]), i }; // If it exists, return the indices } else { map.put(nums[i], i); // If not, store the current number and index in the hash map } } return new int[2]; // Return an empty array (theoretically should not reach this step) } }

content:
Problem # leetcode 20 - Valid Parentheses (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: s = “()” Output: true Example 2:
Input: s = “()[]{}” Output: true Example 3:
Input: s = “(]” Output: false Solution # The problem requires checking if the parentheses are valid, meaning they are correctly matched and in the right order. Valid parentheses must satisfy the following conditions:
Only three types of parentheses: (), [], {}. Every opening bracket must have a corresponding closing bracket, and the order must be correct. If all parentheses are correctly matched, return true; otherwise, return false. This problem can be solved using a Stack, as it is a Last In First Out (LIFO) structure, suitable for handling nested structures.
Approach # Iterate through each character in the string: If it is an opening bracket (, [, {, push it onto the stack. If it is a closing bracket ), ], }, check if the top of the stack is the corresponding opening bracket. If so, pop it. If it is not the corresponding opening bracket or the stack is empty, return false. After iteration, check if the stack is empty. If it is, all brackets are matched, return true; otherwise, return false. Code # import java.util.Stack; class Solution { public boolean isValid(String s) { Stack<Character> stack = new Stack<>(); for(int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) { char c = s.charAt(i); if (c == '(' || c == '[' || c == '{') { stack.push(c); } else if (!stack.isEmpty() && c == ')' && stack.peek() == '(') { stack.pop(); } else if (!stack.isEmpty() && c == ']' && stack.peek() == '[') { stack.pop(); } else if (!stack.isEmpty() && c == '}' && stack.peek() == '{') { stack.pop(); } else { return false; } } return stack.isEmpty(); } }

content:
Problem # leetcode 215 - Kth Largest Element in an Array (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: nums = [3,2,1,5,6,4], k = 2 Output: 5 Example 2:
Input: nums = [3,2,3,1,2,4,5,5,6], k = 4 Output: 4 Solution Approach # The problem requires finding the kth largest element in an array. There are several approaches to solve this problem, with two common methods:
Sorting Method: Sort the array and select the kth largest element. Heap Method: Use a min-heap to maintain k largest elements, where the root of the heap will be the kth largest element. Here, we’ll use a Min-Heap approach as it provides better time complexity. Here’s how it works:
Implementation Details # Initialize a min-heap. Iterate through each element in the array: If the heap size is less than k, add the current element to the heap. If the heap size reaches k and the current element is larger than the heap’s top element (minimum), remove the top element and add the current element. After processing all elements, the top element of the heap will be the kth largest element. This approach achieves a time complexity of O(n log k).
Complete Code # import java.util.PriorityQueue; class Solution { public int findKthLargest(int[] nums, int k) { PriorityQueue<Integer> heap = new PriorityQueue<>(); // Iterate through each element in the array for (int num : nums) { // If heap size is less than k or current element is larger than heap top if (heap.size() < k || heap.peek() <= num) { heap.offer(num); } // If heap size exceeds k, remove the smallest element if (heap.size() > k) { heap.poll(); } } // Return the top element, which is the kth largest return heap.peek(); } }
title: leetcode 215 - Kth Largest Element in an Array

è§£æ³• # åˆå§‹åŒ–ä¸€å€‹æœ€å°å †ï¼ˆMin-Heapï¼‰ã€‚ éæ­·æ•¸çµ„ä¸­çš„æ¯å€‹å…ƒç´ ï¼š å¦‚æœå †çš„å¤§å°å°æ–¼ kï¼Œå°‡ç•¶å‰å…ƒç´ åŠ å…¥å †ä¸­ã€‚ å¦‚æœå †çš„å¤§å°é”åˆ° kï¼Œä¸¦ä¸”ç•¶å‰å…ƒç´ å¤§æ–¼å †é ‚å…ƒç´ ï¼ˆæœ€å°å€¼ï¼‰ï¼Œå‰‡å°‡å †é ‚å…ƒç´ ç§»é™¤ä¸¦å°‡ç•¶å‰å…ƒç´ åŠ å…¥å †ä¸­ã€‚ ç•¶æ‰€æœ‰å…ƒç´ éæ­·å®Œæˆå¾Œï¼Œå †é ‚å…ƒç´ å³ç‚ºç¬¬ k å¤§çš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚ é€™æ¨£æˆ‘å€‘å°±èƒ½åœ¨ O(n log k) çš„æ™‚é–“è¤‡é›œåº¦å…§æ‰¾åˆ°ç¬¬ k å¤§çš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚
å®Œæ•´ç¨‹å¼ç¢¼ # import java.util.PriorityQueue; class Solution { public int findKthLargest(int[] nums, int k) { PriorityQueue<Integer> heap = new PriorityQueue<>(); // éæ­·æ•¸çµ„ä¸­çš„æ¯å€‹å…ƒç´  for (int num : nums) { // å¦‚æœå †çš„å¤§å°å°æ–¼ kï¼Œç›´æ¥æ’å…¥å…ƒç´  if (heap.size() < k || heap.peek() <= num) { heap.offer(num); } // å¦‚æœå †çš„å¤§å°è¶…é kï¼Œç§»é™¤å †é ‚æœ€å°å…ƒç´  if (heap.size() > k) { heap.poll(); } } // è¿”å›å †é ‚å…ƒç´ ï¼Œå³ç‚ºç¬¬ k å¤§çš„å…ƒç´  return heap.peek(); } }

Problem # leetcode 23 - Merge k Sorted Lists (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: lists = [[1,4,5],[1,3,4],[2,6]] Output: [1,1,2,3,4,4,5,6] Example 2:
Input: lists = [] Output: [] Solution # The problem requires merging k sorted linked lists into one sorted linked list. A Min-Heap can be used to solve this, as it helps in selecting the smallest element at each step.
Approach # Use a min-heap to add the head node of each linked list to the heap. Extract the smallest element from the heap and add its next node to the heap. Repeat step 2 until the heap is empty, resulting in a merged sorted linked list. Code # import java.util.PriorityQueue; class Solution { public ListNode mergeKLists(ListNode[] lists) { PriorityQueue<ListNode> heap = new PriorityQueue<>((a, b) -> a.val - b.val); // Add the head node of each linked list to the heap for (ListNode list : lists) { if (list != null) { heap.offer(list); } } ListNode res = new ListNode(0); ListNode cur = res; // Merge all linked lists while (!heap.isEmpty()) { ListNode node = heap.poll(); cur.next = node; cur = cur.next; // If the current node has a next node, add it to the heap if (node.next != null) { heap.offer(node.next); } } return res.next; } }
title: leetcode 23 - Merge k Sorted Lists

Problem # leetcode 394 - Decode String (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: s = “3[a]2[bc]” Output: “aaabcbc” Example 2:
Input: s = “3[a2[c]]” Output: “accaccacc” Example 3:
Input: s = “2[abc]3[cd]ef” Output: “abcabccdcdcdef” Solution # This problem requires decoding a nested format string, such as 3[a2[c]] which needs to be expanded to accaccacc.
Approach: Use a Stack to Simulate the Expansion Process
Number Handling: When encountering a number, accumulate its value, indicating the number of times the subsequent string needs to be repeated. Left Bracket [: Upon encountering [, push the current number and the parsed string onto the stack, and start processing a new substring. Right Bracket ]: Upon encountering ], pop the number and the previous string from the stack, repeat the current substring the corresponding number of times, and append it back. Letter Handling: If it’s a regular letter, directly add it to the current string. This method ensures the ability to handle multi-level nested structures, such as 3[a2[c]].
Code # import java.util.Stack; class Solution { public String decodeString(String s) { StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); Stack<Integer> stNum = new Stack<>(); Stack<StringBuilder> stStr = new Stack<>(); int n = 0; for (int i = 0; i < s.length(); i++) { if (Character.isDigit(s.charAt(i))) { n = n * 10 + (s.charAt(i) - '0'); } else if (s.charAt(i) == '[') { stNum.push(n); n = 0; stStr.push(sb); sb = new StringBuilder(); } else if (s.charAt(i) == ']') { int cnt = stNum.pop(); StringBuilder temp = sb; sb = stStr.pop(); while (cnt-- > 0) { sb.append(temp); } } else { sb.append(s.charAt(i)); } } return sb.toString(); } }
title: leetcode 394 - Decode String

Problem # leetcode 560 - Subarray Sum Equals K (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: nums = [1, 1, 1], k = 2 Output: 2 Example 2:
Input: nums = [1, 2, 3], k = 3 Output: 2 Solution # This problem requires finding the number of subarrays in an array that sum to k. This can be efficiently solved using Prefix Sum and HashMap, with a time complexity of O(n).
What are Prefix Sum and HashMap # Prefix Sum is the cumulative sum of numbers from the start of the array to a certain position. For any subarray [i, j], its sum is sum[j] - sum[i-1], where sum[i-1] is the sum from the start to i-1.
Our goal is to find subarrays whose sum is k. So, whenever we add a number, we check if total - k exists in the HashMap. If it does, it means there is a subarray from a previous position to the current position that sums to k.
Approach # Accumulate each number and record the current total sum, then check if total - k exists in the HashMap. If it does, it indicates a subarray sum of k, and we add the corresponding count to the result.
To account for subarrays starting from the beginning, initialize the HashMap with map = {0: 1}, so when total = k, the result is incremented by one.
Example Explanation: nums = [3, 4, 7, 2, -3, 1, 4, 2], k = 7 # Initial state: map = {0: 1}, total = 0, result = 0 Processing the first number 3:
total = 3 Check if 3 - 7 = -4 exists in map, it doesn’t. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1}. Processing the second number 4:
total = 7 Check if 7 - 7 = 0 exists in map, found it, map.get(0) = 1, result result += 1, result = 1. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1}. Processing the third number 7:
total = 14 Check if 14 - 7 = 7 exists in map, found it, map.get(7) = 1, result result += 1, result = 2. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1, 14: 1}. Processing the fourth number 2:
total = 16 Check if 16 - 7 = 9 exists in map, not found. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1, 14: 1, 16: 1}. Processing the fifth number -3:
total = 13 Check if 13 - 7 = 6 exists in map, not found. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1, 14: 1, 16: 1, 13: 1}. Processing the sixth number 1:
total = 14 Check if 14 - 7 = 7 exists in map, found it, map.get(7) = 1, result result += 1, result = 3. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1, 14: 2, 16: 1, 13: 1}. Processing the seventh number 4:
total = 18 Check if 18 - 7 = 11 exists in map, not found. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1, 14: 2, 16: 1, 13: 1, 18: 1}. Processing the eighth number 2:
total = 20 Check if 20 - 7 = 13 exists in map, found it, map.get(13) = 1, result result += 1, result = 4. Update map, map = {0: 1, 3: 1, 7: 1, 14: 2, 16: 1, 13: 1, 18: 1, 20: 1}. The final result is 4, meaning there are four subarrays that sum to 7.
Code # import java.util.HashMap; class Solution { public int subarraySum(int[] nums, int k) { int result = 0, total = 0; HashMap<Integer, Integer> map = new HashMap<>(); map.put(0, 1); for (int num : nums) { total += num; if (map.containsKey(total - k)) { result += map.get(total - k); } map.put(total, map.getOrDefault(total, 0) + 1); } return result; } }
title: leetcode 560 - Subarray Sum Equals K

content:
Problem # leetcode 735 - Asteroid Collision (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: asteroids = [5, 10, -5] Output: [5, 10] Explanation: The asteroid -5 collides with 10 and is destroyed. Example 2:
Input: asteroids = [8, -8] Output: [] Explanation: The asteroid 8 collides with -8 and both are destroyed. Example 3:
Input: asteroids = [10, 2, -5] Output: [10] Explanation: The asteroid -5 collides with 2 and destroys it, then collides with 10 and is destroyed. Solution Approach # This problem simulates asteroid collisions with the following rules:
Each asteroid’s value represents its size and direction: Positive values indicate movement to the right Negative values indicate movement to the left When asteroids meet: If moving in the same direction, they continue moving If moving in opposite directions, they collide, and the smaller one is destroyed If both asteroids are the same size, both are destroyed We need to track the final state of the asteroids Using a Stack to solve this problem:
Iterate through the asteroids array, pushing asteroids onto the stack When encountering a negative asteroid, check if the top of the stack is positive and handle the collision Continue popping smaller asteroids until finding the appropriate position Finally, return the remaining asteroids in the stack as the result Complete Code # import java.util.Stack; class Solution { public int[] asteroidCollision(int[] asteroids) { Stack<Integer> stack = new Stack<>(); for (int i = 0; i < asteroids.length; i++) { if (asteroids[i] > 0) { stack.push(asteroids[i]); } else { while (!stack.isEmpty() && stack.peek() > 0 && stack.peek() < -asteroids[i]) { stack.pop(); } if (!stack.isEmpty() && stack.peek() == -asteroids[i]) { stack.pop(); } else if (stack.isEmpty() || stack.peek() < 0) { stack.push(asteroids[i]); } } } int[] res = new int[stack.size()]; for (int i = res.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) { res[i] = stack.pop(); } return res; } }

Problem # leetcode 739 - Daily Temperatures (Click the link for problem description)
Examples # Example 1:
Input: temperatures = [73, 74, 75, 71, 69, 72, 76, 73] Output: [1, 1, 4, 2, 1, 1, 0, 0] Explanation: After day 0, it takes 1 day to get warmer (74 is higher than 73). Example 2:
Input: temperatures = [30, 40, 50, 60] Output: [1, 1, 1, 0] Example 3:
Input: temperatures = [30, 60, 90] Output: [1, 1, 0] Solution Approach # This problem requires finding how many days you need to wait to get a warmer temperature for each day.
Solution: Monotonic Decreasing Stack
Create a Stack to store temperature indices. Iterate through the temperatures array from right to left. If the current temperature temperatures[i] is greater than or equal to the temperature at the stack’s top index, pop from the stack. If the stack is not empty, calculate the difference in days with the top index and store it in the result array. Push the current index onto the stack. This method ensures that the temperatures corresponding to indices in the stack are in decreasing order, allowing us to quickly find the next warmer temperature.
Complete Code # import java.util.Stack; class Solution { public int[] dailyTemperatures(int[] temperatures) { int n = temperatures.length; int[] res = new int[n]; Stack<Integer> stack = new Stack<>(); for (int i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) { while (!stack.isEmpty() && temperatures[i] >= temperatures[stack.peek()]) { stack.pop(); } if (!stack.isEmpty()) { res[i] = stack.peek() - i; } stack.push(i); } return res; } }

Problem # leetcode 1231 - Divide Chocolate (Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: sweetness = [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9], K = 5
Output: 6
Explanation: You can divide the chocolate to [1,2,3], [4,5], [6], [7], [8], [9]
Example 2:
Input: sweetness = [5,6,7,8,9,1,2,3,4], K = 8
Output: 1
Explanation: There is only one way to cut the bar into 9 pieces.
Example 3:
Input: sweetness = [1,2,2,1,2,2,1,2,2], K = 2
Output: 5
Explanation: You can divide the chocolate to [1,2,2], [1,2,2], [1,2,2]
Solution Approach # The input is an array of sweetness values and the number of friends K (including yourself) to share with.
The output should be the maximum possible minimum sweetness when dividing the chocolate into K+1 pieces.
This problem is similar to leetcode410, but with a different search objective.
Comparison between Leetcode 410 and Leetcode 1231 # Leetcode 410: Minimize the maximum value
Update logic: When a feasible solution is found, we try a smaller maximum value, right=mid.
Since we need to explore smaller values, we use floor division for the middle value.
Leetcode 1231: Maximize the minimum value
Update logic: When a feasible solution is found, we try a larger minimum value, left=mid.
Since we need to explore larger values, we use ceiling division for the middle value.
For this problem of maximizing the minimum value, we set the binary search range as follows:
Left boundary (min): The minimum sweetness value in the array.
min=min(sweetness) Right boundary (max): The sum of all sweetness values.
max=âˆ‘(sweetness) Binary Search Process:
Initialize the search range as [min,max]. Calculate the middle value mid=(min+max+1)/2. Create a canSplit method to verify if mid is feasible: If feasible, update left boundary min=mid to try larger sweetness. If not feasible, update right boundary max=mid-1. Finally, when min(left)==max(right), we’ve found the answer. Complete Code # class Solution { public int maximizeSweetness(int [] sweetness, int k) { int left = Integer.MAX_VALUE; int right = 0; for (int sweet:sweetness){ if (sweet < left){ left = sweet; } right+=sweet; } while (left < right){ int mid = left + (right - left+1)/2; if(canSplit(sweetness,k,mid)){ left = mid; }else { right = mid-1; } } return left; } public boolean canSplit(int [] sweetness, int k,int minSweetness) { int count = 0; int sum = 0; for(int sweet:sweetness){ sum+=sweet; if(sum>=minSweetness){ sum = 0; count++; } } if(count>=k+1){ return true; } return false; } }

Problem # leetcode 141 - Linked List Cycle(Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: head = [3,2,0,-4], pos = 1
Output: true
Explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 1st node (0-indexed).
Example 2:
Input: head = [1,2], pos = 0
Output: true
Explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 0th node.
Example 3:
Input: head = [1], pos = -1
Output: false
Explanation: There is no cycle in the linked list.
Solution # This problem checks if a Linked List has a cycle, returning true or false. The solution uses the fast and slow pointer technique to detect a cycle: The slow pointer moves one step at a time, while the fast pointer moves two steps. If they meet, there is a cycle.
Code # public class Solution { public boolean hasCycle(ListNode head) { ListNode fast = head; // Initialize fast pointer ListNode slow = head; // Initialize slow pointer while(fast!=null&&fast.next!=null){ // While fast pointer and its next node are not null fast = fast.next.next; // Fast pointer moves two steps slow = slow.next; // Slow pointer moves one step if(fast == slow){ // If fast and slow pointers meet return true; // There is a cycle } } return false; // No cycle } }
title: leetcode 141 - Linked List Cycle

é¡Œç›® # leetcode 141 - Linked List Cycle(é¡Œç›®èªªæ˜è«‹é»é€£çµ)
Example 1:
Input: head = [3,2,0,-4], pos = 1
Output: true
Explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 1st node (0-indexed).
Example 2:

Output: true
Explanation: There is a cycle in the linked list, where the tail connects to the 0th node.
Example 3:
Input: head = [1], pos = -1
Output: false
Explanation: There is no cycle in the linked list.

Problem # leetcode 237 - Delete Node in a Linked List(Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: head = [4,5,1,9], node = 5
Output: [4,1,9]
Explanation: You are given the second node with value 5,
the linked list should become 4 -> 1 -> 9 after calling your function.
Example 2:
Input: head = [4,5,1,9], node = 1
Output: [4,5,9]
Explanation: You are given the third node with value 1,
the linked list should become 4 -> 5 -> 9 after calling your function.
Solution # This problem involves implementing the Delete Node function for a Linked List.
Code # class Solution { public void deleteNode(ListNode node) { node.val=node.next.val; node.next=node.next.next; } }

Problem # leetcode 1062 - Split Array Largest Sum(Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: nums = [7,2,5,10,8], k = 2
Output: 18
Explanation: There are four ways to split nums into two subarrays. The best way is to split it into [7,2,5] and [10,8], where the largest sum among the two subarrays is only 18.
Example 2:
Input: nums = [1,2,3,4,5], k = 2
Output: 9
Explanation: There are four ways to split nums into two subarrays. The best way is to split it into [1,2,3] and [4,5], where the largest sum among the two subarrays is only 9.
Solution # The input is an array, and the output is the largest sum among the subarrays when split into k groups. For example:
nums = [7,2,5,10,8] can be split into k = 2 groups,
[7,2,5] and [10,8], where the largest sum is 18 (10+8).
Our goal is to minimize the largest sum of the subarrays (i.e., the answer), which is an ordered range problem because:
When the number of splits k increases, the sum of each subarray decreases (subarrays are shorter).
When the number of splits k decreases, the sum of each subarray increases (subarrays are longer).
The problem can be transformed into checking whether a sum satisfies the condition of dividing the array into k subarrays, with each subarray’s sum not exceeding the sum.
Its monotonicity also meets the conditions for using binary search, with the binary search range as follows:
Left boundary (min): The maximum value in the array, because the sum of any subarray is at least equal to the maximum value in the array.
min=max(nums) Right boundary (max): The total sum of all numbers, because when k=1, all numbers are in one subarray.
max=âˆ‘(nums) Binary search process:
Initialize the binary range as [min,max]. Calculate the middle value mid=(min+max)/2. Establish the canSplit method to verify whether mid is feasible (whether its maximum value mid can be split into k groups): If feasible, update the right boundary max=mid, trying a smaller maximum sum. If not feasible, update the left boundary min=mid+1. Finally, when min(left)==max(right), the answer is found Code # class Solution { public int splitArray(int[] nums, int k) { int left = 0; int right = 0; for(int num:nums){ if(num>left){ left = num; } right+=num; } while(left<right){ int mid = left + (right - left)/2; if(canSplit(nums,k,mid)){ right = mid; }else{ left = mid+1; } } return left; } public boolean canSplit(int nums[],int k,int maxValue) { int sum = 0; int count = 1; for(int num:nums){ if(sum+num>maxValue){ count++; sum = num; if(count>k){ return false; } }else { sum+=num; } } return true; } }
title: leetcode 410 - Split Array Largest Sum

Problem # leetcode 237 - Reverse Linked List II(Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5], left = 2, right = 4
Output: [1,4,3,2,5]
Example 2:
Input: head = [5], left = 1, right = 1
Output: [5]
Solution # Given a linked list and two integers, left and right, return the linked list after reversing the nodes from position left to right.
For example, given 1->2->3->4->5 with left = 2 and right = 4, the returned list should be 1->4->3->2->5.
To solve this, we perform step-by-step swapping for each reversal. First, create a dummy node to avoid losing the head when it gets reversed, then start with a prev node from the dummy. The initial setup is:
D->1->2->3->4->5 p
Next, move prev to the node before the left position, and set current and temp to the next two nodes:
D->1->2->3->4->5 p c t Then perform the swap: t.next: changes from 3->4 to 3->2 c.next: changes from 2->3 to 2->4 p.next: changes from 1->2 to 1->3 The linked list becomes D->1->3->2->4->5
Proceed to the next swap:
D->1->3->2->4->5 p c t Then perform the swap: t.next: changes from 4->5 to 4->3 c.next: changes from 2->4 to 2->5 p.next: changes from 1->3 to 1->4 The linked list becomes D->1->4->3->2->5
Return Dummy.next as the answer.
Code # /** * Definition for singly-linked list. * public class ListNode { * int val; * ListNode next; * ListNode() {} * ListNode(int val) { this.val = val; } * ListNode(int val, ListNode next) { this.val = val; this.next = next; } * } */ class Solution { public ListNode reverseBetween(ListNode head, int left, int right) { if (head == null || left == right) { return head; } ListNode dummy = new ListNode(0); dummy.next = head; ListNode prev = dummy; for(int i=1;i<left;i++){ prev = prev.next; } ListNode cur = prev.next; for(int i=0;i<right-left;i++){ ListNode temp = cur.next; cur.next = temp.next; temp.next = prev.next; prev.next = temp; } return dummy.next; } }
title: leetcode 92 - Reverse Linked List II

Problem # leetcode 1047 - Remove All Adjacent Duplicates In String(Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: s = “abbaca”
Output: “ca”
Explanation: For example, in “abbaca” we could remove “bb” since the letters are adjacent and equal, and this is the only possible move.
The result of this move is that the string is “aaca”, of which only “aa” is possible, so the final string is “ca”.
Example 2:
Input: s = “azxxzy”
Output: “ay”
Solution # The input is a string, and the task is to remove adjacent duplicate characters. This can be implemented using the Two Pointers technique.
For example:
Use two pointers, i and j, where i traverses new characters and j checks conditions and searches for the answer.
i ->
abbaca
j ->
aabbaca
Move forward and overwrite simultaneously. If j’s current position and j-1 are adjacent duplicates, move j back by 2 (removing these two duplicates),
i ->
abbbbaca
j <-Â (-2)
abbaca
j moves back to position 0
abbaca
Continue moving forward and overwriting
i ->
abbaca
j ->
aabaca
If j and j-1 are duplicates again, move j back to -1
j
aabaca
Continue overwriting
i->
abbaca
j ->
cabaca
The two pointers continue until i reaches the last position
i
abbaca
j
cabaca
Code # class Solution { public String removeDuplicates(String s) { int j=0; // Initialize pointer j char[] res = s.toCharArray(); // Convert string to character array for(int i=0;i<s.length();++i,++j){ // Traverse character array res[j] = res[i]; // Assign current character to j pointer position if(j>0 && res[j]==res[j-1]){ // If current character is the same as the previous one j-=2; // Move j pointer back two steps } } return new String(res,0,j); // Return the string after removing duplicates } } Stack Solution # Initially, the intuitive approach is to use a stack to solve this problem,
leveraging the LIFO (Last In First Out) mechanism, placing each character into the stack for comparison,
checking if the two adjacent values are the same each time;
The value to be placed into the stack
The top value of the stack
Stack : ab
Put in : baca
If they are the same, pop the stack; if not, continue placing into the stack for comparison.
After completion, the stack will contain the characters without duplicates, which can be formed into a string as the answer.
class Solution { public String removeDuplicates(String s) { Stack<Character> stack = new Stack<>(); // Initialize a stack char[] chars = s.toCharArray(); // Convert string to character array for(char c : chars){ // Traverse character array if(!stack.isEmpty() && stack.peek() == c){ // If stack is not empty and top character is the same as current stack.pop(); // Pop the top character }else { stack.push(c); // Otherwise, push the current character onto the stack } } StringBuilder result = new StringBuilder(); // Initialize result string for (char c : stack) { // Traverse stack result.append(c); // Add character to result string } return result.toString(); // Return result string } }

class Solution { public String removeDuplicates(String s) { Stack<Character> stack = new Stack<>(); // åˆå§‹åŒ–ä¸€å€‹æ£§ char[] chars = s.toCharArray(); // å°‡å­—ä¸²è½‰æ›ç‚ºå­—ç¬¦æ•¸çµ„ for(char c : chars){ // éæ­·å­—ç¬¦æ•¸çµ„ if(!stack.isEmpty() && stack.peek() == c){ // å¦‚æœæ£§ä¸ç‚ºç©ºä¸”æ£§é ‚å­—ç¬¦èˆ‡ç•¶å‰å­—ç¬¦ç›¸åŒ stack.pop(); // å½ˆå‡ºæ£§é ‚å­—ç¬¦ }else { stack.push(c); // å¦å‰‡å°‡ç•¶å‰å­—ç¬¦å£“å…¥æ£§ } } StringBuilder result = new StringBuilder(); // åˆå§‹åŒ–çµæœå­—ä¸² for (char c : stack) { // éæ­·æ£§ result.append(c); // å°‡å­—ç¬¦æ·»åŠ åˆ°çµæœå­—ä¸² } return result.toString(); // è¿”å›çµæœå­—ä¸² } }

Problem # leetcode 1062 - Longest Repeating Substring (Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: “abcd”
Output: 0
Explanation: There is no repeating substring.
Example 2:
Input: “abbaba”
Output: 2
Explanation: The longest repeating substrings are “ab” and “ba”, each of which occurs twice.
Example 3:
Input: “aabcaabdaab”
Output: 3
Explanation: The longest repeating substring is “aab”, which occurs 3 times.
Example 4:
Input: “aaaaa”
Output: 4
Explanation: The longest repeating substring is “aaaa”, which occurs twice.
Solution Approach # The input is a string, and we need to find the length of the longest repeating substring.
We can solve this using ordered intervals and monotonicity properties:
For example, if the input string is S = “aabcaabdaab”, we check for repetitions at different substring lengths.
Substring Length and Repetition: Substring Length L (aabcaabdaab)
L Has Repeating Substring Repeating Parts 1 Yes Single characters like “a” repeat multiple times 2 Yes Substrings like “aa” or “ab” repeat 3 Yes Substring “aab” repeats 4 No No repeating substrings of length 4 5 No No repeating substrings of length 5 6 No No repeating substrings of length 6 Ordered Intervals: From 1 to 6 (substring lengths) is ordered, as the existence of repeating substrings follows a pattern with length changes.
Monotonicity:
When Lâ‰¤3, repeating substrings exist.
When Lâ‰¥4, no repeating substrings exist.
We use Binary Search to find the maximum repeating number in this ordered array,
and write a separate method using HashSet to check for repetitions.
Complete Code # class Solution { public int longestRepeatingSubstring(String s) { int left = 1, right = s.length(); while(left < right) { int mid = left + (right - left + 1) / 2; if(hasRepeatingSubstring(s, mid)) { left = mid ; }else { right = mid -1; } } return left; } public boolean hasRepeatingSubstring(String s,int length) { HashSet<String> set = new HashSet<>(); for (int i = 0; i <= s.length()-length; i++) { if(set.contains(s.substring(i,i+length))) { return true; }else{ set.add(s.substring(i,i+length)); } } return false; } }

content:
Problem # leetcode 26 - Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
Example 1:
Input: nums = [1,1,2]
Output: 2, nums = [1,2,_]
Explanation: Your function should return k = 2, with the first two elements of nums being 1 and 2 respectively.
It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned k (hence they are underscores).
Example 2:
Input: nums = [0,0,1,1,1,2,2,3,3,4]
Output: 5, nums = [0,1,2,3,4,,,,,_]
Explanation: Your function should return k = 5, with the first five elements of nums being 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 respectively.
It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned k (hence they are underscores).
Solution # The input is a sorted array, and the task is to remove duplicates in-place such that each element appears only once and return the new length. We use two pointers, i and j, where i traverses the array and j keeps track of the position of the last unique element.
Step 1: Start with i at 1, since the first element is always unique. Compare nums[i] with nums[j-1]. If they are the same, move i forward.
Step 2: If nums[i] is different from nums[j-1], place nums[i] at nums[j] and increment j.
Step 3: Continue this process until i reaches the end of the array.
Step 4: The function returns j, which is the length of the array with unique elements.
Code # class Solution { public int removeDuplicates(int[] nums) { int j = 1; // Initialize the second pointer for (int i = 1; i < nums.length; i++) { // Start from the second element if (nums[i] != nums[j - 1]) { // If the current element is not a duplicate nums[j] = nums[i]; // Move it to the next position in the array j++; // Increment the second pointer } } return j; // Return the length of the array without duplicates } }

Problem # leetcode 344 - Reverse String(Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: s = [“h”,“e”,“l”,“l”,“o”]
Output: [“o”,“l”,“l”,“e”,“h”]
Example 2:
Input: s = [“H”,“a”,“n”,“n”,“a”,“h”]
Output: [“h”,“a”,“n”,“n”,“a”,“H”]
Solution # The input is an array, and the task is to reverse the array in place without using extra space. We use two pointers, i starting at 0 and j at the array length minus 1. As the loop progresses, i increments and j decrements, stopping when i > j, indicating the middle has been reached and swapping is complete.
Code # class Solution { public char[] reverseString(char[] s) { // initialize int i = 0; int j = s.length-1; while(i<j){ char tmp = s[i]; s[i] = s[j]; s[j] = tmp; i++; j--; } return s; } }

Problem # leetcode 42 - Trapping Rain Water (Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: height = [0,1,0,2,1,0,1,3,2,1,2,1]
Output: 6
Explanation: The above elevation map (black section) is represented by array [0,1,0,2,1,0,1,3,2,1,2,1].
In this case, 6 units of rain water (blue section) are being trapped.
Example 2:
Input: height = [4,2,0,3,2,5]
Output: 9
Solution # The input is an array representing the height of walls as shown in the image above. The task is to calculate the total amount of water that can be trapped by these walls.
This problem can be solved using the two-pointer technique, recording the positions of left and right pointers. Since water flows to lower areas, we record the highest positions from the outside inwards using maxLeft and maxRight for the two pointers. At each position, the trapped water is calculated as the difference between the highest height on either side and the current height. For example, in the illustration:
When the left pointer reaches a position:
The current trapped water is maxLeft - current, which is the previously recorded 1 - current height 0 = 1
When the right pointer reaches a position:
The current trapped water is maxLeft - current, which is the previously recorded 2 - current height 1 = 1 Finally, when left and right pointers meet, the program ends, and the total water trapped is output. Code # class Solution { public int trap(int[] height) { int left = 0,right = height.length -1; int maxLeft = height[left],maxRight = height[right]; int water = 0; while(left<right){ if(maxLeft<maxRight){ left++; maxLeft = Math.max(maxLeft,height[left]); water+=maxLeft - height[left]; }else{ right--; maxRight = Math.max(maxRight,height[right]); water+=maxRight - height[right]; } } return water; } }

Problem # leetcode 80 - Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array II (Click the link for problem description)
Example 1:
Input: nums = [1,1,1,2,2,3] Output: 5, nums = [1,1,2,2,3,_] Explanation: Your function should return k = 5, with the first five elements of nums being 1, 1, 2, 2 and 3 respectively. It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned k (hence they are underscores).
Example 2:
Input: nums = [0,0,1,1,1,1,2,3,3] Output: 7, nums = [0,0,1,1,2,3,3,,] Explanation: Your function should return k = 7, with the first seven elements of nums being 0, 0, 1, 1, 2, 3 and 3 respectively. It does not matter what you leave beyond the returned k (hence they are underscores).
Solution # This problem is a variation of leetcode 26 and can be solved using the Two Pointers technique. The output array should contain the first K sorted numbers without any number appearing more than twice.
The approach is similar to that of problem 26, with pointers i and j for traversal and replacement. Since numbers can appear more than twice, the index starts at 2. i traverses the array, and when the current data differs from the value at j-2, it is overwritten. Since the input is already sorted, the first two numbers do not need to be overwritten.
When the first swap point is reached, i is at position 2, differing from the value at j-2, which is 1, so the first swap occurs. At this point, nums = [1,1,2,2,2,3]
Continue until the last overwrite, resulting in nums = [1,1,2,2,3,3]
Code # class Solution { public int removeDuplicates(int[] nums) { int j = 2; for (int i = 2; i < nums.length; i++) { if (nums[i] != nums[j - 2]) { nums[j] = nums[i]; j++; } } return j; } }
title: leetcode 80 - Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array II
